at.tgm.insy.theexporter.connection

Class Connection

  • java.lang.Object
    • at.tgm.insy.theexporter.connection.Connection
  • Direct Known Subclasses:
    MySQLConnection

    public abstract class Connection
extends java.lang.Object
    This abstract class is giving a basis for building a class responsible for the connection to a Database. The DataSource Method can simply be overwritten to serve the needs according to the Database one has, e.g. MySQL or PostgreSQL. Since this Application is based on the Factory Design Pattern, you can simply use the already given Methods with ease to do whatever you desire to do with your Database.

    • Method Detail

      • createConnection

        public abstract javax.sql.DataSource createConnection(java.lang.String host,
                                                      java.lang.String user,
                                                      java.lang.String password)
        Every time one wants to connect to a specific Database, he/she will have to overwrite this method to suit the Database type. It will return a DataSource Object which can then be used
        Parameters:
        host - Server host (IP or Domain)
        user - Designated user with given rights
        password - Password to the user's account
        Returns:
        DataSource Object

      • start

        public void start(java.lang.String host,
                  java.lang.String user,
                  java.lang.String password,
                  java.lang.String database)
        Creates a connection to a Database with the given information.
        Parameters:
        host - Server host
        user - Designated user with given rights
        password - Password to the user's account
        database - The Database you want to connect to

      • sendQuery

        public javax.swing.table.DefaultTableModel sendQuery(java.lang.String query)
                                              throws java.sql.SQLException
        With this method, you can send your command to the Database after a connection has been established. You will receive the output in an nice to manage and easy to use table and are then able to do whatever you want with the results of the query. Please note that the guidelines of checkQuery() must be followed.
        Parameters:
        query - The query that shall be executed
        Returns:
        A table with the results of the query
        Throws:
        java.sql.SQLException - SQL Exception

        Close the connection to the database and set it back to null
